sen.j: 乃木 静子（のぎ しずこ、安政6年11月6日 (旧暦)（1859年11月29日） - 大正元年（1912年）9月13日）は、幕末・明治期の女性で、陸軍大将・乃木希典の妻。
sen.e: Shizuko NOGI (November 29, 1859-September 13, 1912) was a woman who lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period and a wife of Maresuke NOGI who was Army General.
Shizuko NOGI (November 29, 1859-September 13, 1912) was a woman who lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period and the wife of Maresuke NOGI who was Army General.
Shizuko NOGI (November 29, 1859-September 13, 1912) was a woman who lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period and the wife of Maresuke NOGI who was Army General.

sen.j: 安政6年11月6日、鹿児島藩医・湯地定之・湯地貞子夫妻の4女（7人兄弟姉妹の末っ子）として出生。
sen.e: On November 29, 1859, she was born as the fourth daughter (the youngest child among seven brothers and sisters) between Sadayuki YUCHI, a doctor of the Kagoshima domain, and Sadako YUCHI.
On November 29, 1859, she was born as the fourth daughter (the youngest child among seven brothers and sisters) between Sadayuki YUCHI, a doctor of the Kagoshima domain, and Sadako YUCHI.
On November 29, 1859, she was born as the fourth daughter (the youngest child among seven brothers and sisters) between Sadayuki YUCHI, a doctor of the Kagoshima domain, and Sadako YUCHI.

sen.j: 幼名はお七、またはお志知。
sen.e: Her childhood name was Ohichi or Oshichi.
Her childhood name was Ohichi or Oshichi.
Her childhood name was Ohichi or Oshichi.

sen.j: 1872年12月2日、当時、数え年14歳の時に海外留学から帰国した長兄・湯地定基に呼び寄せられる形で家族揃って東京赤坂 (東京都港区)溜池2番地の湯地定基邸に転居、東京府麹町区にある麹町女學校に入学する。
sen.e: On December 2, 1872, all her family moved to his eldest brother Sadamoto YUCHI's residence at 2 Akasaka, Tokyo, called by Sadamoto who had just come back to Japan from studying abroad when she was 14 years old in the age by the traditional Japanese system, and she entered Kojimachi Girls' School at the Kojimachi Ward, Tokyo Prefecture.

On December 2, 1872, all her family moved to his eldest brother Sadamoto YUCHI's residence at 2 Akasaka, Tokyo, called by Sadamoto who had just come back to Japan from studying abroad when she was 14 years old in the age by the traditional Japanese system, and she entered Kojimachi Girls' School at the Kojimachi Ward, Tokyo Prefecture.

On December 2, 1872, all her family moved to his eldest brother Sadamoto YUCHI's residence at 2 Akasaka, Tokyo, called by Sadamoto who had just come back to Japan from studying abroad when she was 14 years old in the age by the traditional Japanese system, and she entered Kojimachi Girls' School at the Kojimachi Ward, Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 麹町女學校は明治初期に創立され、明治中期に廃校になったため、現存しない。
sen.e: Kojimachi Girls' School was established at the beginning of the Meiji period and abolished in the middle of the Meiji period, so that it does not exist now.
Kojimachi Girls' School was established at the beginning of the Meiji period and abolished in the middle of the Meiji period, so it does not exist now.
Kojimachi Girls' School was established at the beginning of the Meiji period and abolished in the middle of the Meiji period, so it does not exist now.

sen.j: また、麹町学園女子高等学校が静子の出身校の流れを汲む学校と噂されるも、確たる証拠はいまのところ発見されていない。
sen.e: In addition, although it is said that Kojimachi Gakuen Girl's High School succeeded Shizuko's alma mater, no evidence has been discovered so far.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, although it is said that Kojimachi Gakuen Girl's High School succeeded Shizuko's alma mater, no evidence has been discovered so far.
In addition, although it is said that Kojimachi Gakuen Girl's High School succeeded Shizuko's alma mater, no evidence has been discovered so far.

sen.j: が、それを示唆する文献は多数存在する。
sen.e: However, there are many documents which suggest it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, there are many documents which suggest it.
However, there are many documents which suggest it.

sen.j: 大日本帝国陸軍軍人・伊地知幸介や野津鎮雄らの勧めにより、躊躇しながらも数え年20歳で希典と結婚。
sen.e: Recommended by Kosuke IJICHI and Shizuo NOZU who were military men, she hesitantly married with Maresuke at the age of 20 in the age by the traditional Japanese system.
Recommended by Kosuke IJICHI and Shizuo NOZU who were military men, she hesitantly married Maresuke at the age of 20 in the age by the traditional Japanese system.
Recommended by Kosuke IJICHI and Shizuo NOZU who were military men, she hesitantly married Maresuke at the age of 20 in the age by the traditional Japanese system.

sen.j: 「静子の方が希典に対して興味・想いを持っていた」とされる文献もあるが、これは間違いである。
sen.e: Some documents describe that 'Shizuko was interested in Maresuke and loved him,' but this is wrong.
Some documents describe that 'Shizuko was interested in Maresuke and loved him,' but this is wrong.
Some documents describe that 'Shizuko was interested in Maresuke and loved him,' but this is wrong.

sen.j: 事実は逆で、希典の方が「鹿児島の女子しか嫁に貰わぬ」と述べている。
sen.e: The opposite is true and Maresuke said, 'I will marry only with a woman from Kagoshima.'
The opposite is true and Maresuke said, 'I will marry only a woman from Kagoshima.'
The opposite is true and Maresuke said, 'I will marry only a woman from Kagoshima.'

sen.j: 長男・乃木勝典を始め、4人の子宝に恵まれるが、勝典と次男・乃木保典を残し、下の二人は生後、間もなく夭折する。
sen.e: They were blessed with four children including their eldest son Katsusuke NOGI, but younger two children died soon after the birth, leaving Katsusuke and the second son Yasusuke NOGI.
They were blessed with four children including their eldest son Katsusuke NOGI, but younger two children died soon after the birth, leaving Katsusuke and the second son Yasusuke NOGI.
They were blessed with four children including their eldest son Katsusuke NOGI, but younger two children died soon after the birth, leaving Katsusuke and the second son Yasusuke NOGI.

sen.j: 新婚当時は生活も厳しく、貧しい生活をしている上に姑・乃木寿子（乃木久子表記での文献有り）との確執もあり、苦労・苦悩が続き、1年半ほど勝典・保典を連れて別居している。
sen.e: When she just got married, she continuously suffered from troubles such as poor life and a conflict with her mother-in-law Hisako (the letter '寿子' is also written as '久子' in some documents) NOGI, so that she separated for one and half year with Katsusuke and Yasusuke.

When she was just married, she continuously suffered from troubles such as poor life and a conflict with her mother-in-law Hisako (the letter '寿子' is also written as '久子' in some documents) NOGI, so she was separated for one and half year from Katsusuke and Yasusuke.
sen.cmt: gotは不要です。So thatのthatは不要です。She was separated
sen.e: When she was just married, she continuously suffered from troubles such as poor life and a conflict with her mother-in-law Hisako (the letter '寿子' is also written as '久子' in some documents) NOGI, so she was separated for one and half year from Katsusuke and Yasusuke.

sen.j: 日露戦争が開戦し、出征する希典（出征時は既に陸軍中将 - 陸軍大将）・勝典・保典（二人とも出征時は既に陸軍少尉）に東京・銀座の高級化粧品店・資生堂で1つ9円もする香水2つと8円の香水1つの計3つを購入し、贈る。
sen.e: When the Russo-Japanese War began and Maresuke (who had been already the lieutenant general and the Army General at that time), Katsusuke and Yasusuke (both of them had been already junior lieutenants of Army) left for the front, she bought the three bottles of fragrant water among which the two cost nine yen and the one cost eight yen and presented to them.

When the Russo-Japanese War began and Maresuke (who had been already the lieutenant general and the Army General at that time), Katsusuke and Yasusuke (both of them had been already junior lieutenants of Army) left for the front, she bought three bottles of fragrant water among which two cost nine yen and the one cost eight yen and presented to them.

When the Russo-Japanese War began and Maresuke (who had been already the lieutenant general and the Army General at that time), Katsusuke and Yasusuke (both of them had been already junior lieutenants of Army) left for the front, she bought three bottles of fragrant water among which two cost nine yen and the one cost eight yen and presented to them.

sen.j: 当初、静子は9円の香水を3つ購入して3人にそれぞれ贈るつもりだったが、9円の香水が2つしかなかったため、9円の香水を勝典と保典に、8円の香水を希典に贈った。
sen.e: At first, Shizuko intended to buy three bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen and present them to each person, but since only two bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen were sold, she presented the one which cost nine yen to Katsusuke and Yasusuke, and the other which cost eight yen to Maresuke.

At first, Shizuko intended to buy three bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen and present them to each person, but since only two bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen were sold, she presented the one which cost nine yen to Katsusuke and Yasusuke, and the other which cost eight yen to Maresuke.

At first, Shizuko intended to buy three bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen and present them to each person, but since only two bottles of fragrant water which cost nine yen were sold, she presented the one which cost nine yen to Katsusuke and Yasusuke, and the other which cost eight yen to Maresuke.

sen.j: 当時の9円というのは、成人女性が精一杯働いて稼ぐことの出来る平均給与の約2か月分に相当する。
sen.e: The nine yen in those days corresponded to about two-months average salary which a woman could earn with hard working.
The nine yen in those days corresponded to about two-months average salary which a woman could earn with hard working.
The nine yen in those days corresponded to about two-months average salary which a woman could earn with hard working.

sen.j: 静子がそこまでして高価な香水を贈ったのは、もし戦死した後、遺体から異臭が放たれれば夫と愛息子が不憫この上ないという妻として、母親としての哀しいまでの家族を想いやる愛の表現であった。
sen.e: The reason why Shizuko presented such expensive fragrant water was that it was a pity if her husband and loving sons died in the battle and their bodies smelled an unusual odor, which was her love for family as a wife and a mother.

The reason why Shizuko presented such expensive fragrant water was that it was a pity if her husband and loving sons died in the battle and their bodies smelled an unusual odor, which was her love for family as a wife and a mother.

The reason why Shizuko presented such expensive fragrant water was that it was a pity if her husband and loving sons died in the battle and their bodies smelled an unusual odor, which was her love for family as a wife and a mother.

sen.j: 明治37年5月27日、勝典が金州南山（通称：金山または南山）で銃弾に打たれて腸を損傷、向こう側が丸見えになるほどの風穴が開いた。
sen.e: On May 27, 1904, Katsusuke was hit by a gun at Jinshan Nanzan (commonly called Jinshan or Nanzan) and injured in the stomach so hardly as an air hole was opened.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On May 27, 1904, Katsusuke was hit by a gun at Jinshan Nanzan (commonly called Jinshan or Nanzan) and he was injured in the stomach so hard, an air hole was opened.
sen.cmt: as anではわかりにくいのでかえました。
sen.e: On May 27, 1904, Katsusuke was hit by a gun at Jinshan Nanzan (commonly called Jinshan or Nanzan) and he was injured in the stomach so hard, an air hole was opened.

sen.j: 軍医による手術・治療を受けるも出血多量で戦死した。
sen.e: He had surgery done and received treatment by a field doctor, but died from excessive bleeding.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He had surgery and received treatment by a field doctor, but died from excessive bleeding.
He had surgery and received treatment by a field doctor, but died from excessive bleeding.

sen.j: 勝典は死後、1階級特進で陸軍中尉に昇進。
sen.e: Katsusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.
Katsusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.
Katsusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.

sen.j: この後、勝典の戦死の知らせを聞いた静子は深い哀しみに暮れ、三日三晩泣き続けた。
sen.e: After that, Shizuko who was let to know Katsusuke's death was prostrated with sorrow and continued to cry for three days and nights.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, Shizuko who had been informed Katsusuke's death was prostrated with sorrow and continued to cry for three days and nights.
sen.cmt: who had been informedにかえました。
sen.e: After that, Shizuko who had been informed Katsusuke's death was prostrated with sorrow and continued to cry for three days and nights.

sen.j: 一説には血の涙を流したともいわれる。
sen.e: Some people say that she bled tears.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some people say that she bled tears.
Some people say that she bled tears.

sen.j: （ここで記述する血の涙とは、恐らくは血を流しているかのように見えるほど赤く泣き腫らした顔を指しているものと想われるが、実際に血の混じった涙を流したと記す文献もあり、真偽は不明である。）
sen.e: (It can be guessed that this bleeding of tears showed her read face swollen with crying as if she bled tears, but some documents describe that she actually shed tears with blood, therefore, the truth is unclear.)

(It can be guessed that this bleeding of tears showed her read face swollen with crying as if she bled tears, but some documents describe that she actually shed tears with blood, therefore, the truth is unclear.)

(It can be guessed that this bleeding of tears showed her read face swollen with crying as if she bled tears, but some documents describe that she actually shed tears with blood, therefore, the truth is unclear.)

sen.j: 明治37年11月30日、苦戦を強いられていた帝国陸軍は第3軍司令官・希典と児玉源太郎陸軍大将の戦略で203高地を進軍していたが、この時に保典が砲弾に打たれたショックで岸壁から滑落、岩場に激突し、頭が砕けて戦死した（即死）。
sen.e: On November 30, 1904, when the Imperial Army which faces an uphill battle attacked 203 high land under the strategy of the third commander Maresuke and the Army General Gentaro KODAMA, Yasusuke was hit by crump, fell down from a quay and crashed into rocks, and his head was pulverized and he died (immediate death).

On November 30, 1904, when the Imperial Army which faces an uphill battle attacked 203 high land under the strategy of the third commander Maresuke and the Army General Gentaro KODAMA, Yasusuke was hit by crump, fell down from a quay and crashed into rocks, and his head was pulverized and he died (immediate death).

On November 30, 1904, when the Imperial Army which faces an uphill battle attacked 203 high land under the strategy of the third commander Maresuke and the Army General Gentaro KODAMA, Yasusuke was hit by crump, fell down from a quay and crashed into rocks, and his head was pulverized and he died (immediate death).

sen.j: 保典も勝典と同じく、1階級特進で陸軍中尉に昇進。
sen.e: As well as Katsusuke, Yasusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.
As well as Katsusuke, Yasusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.
As well as Katsusuke, Yasusuke was promoted to the First Lieutenant of Army by special treatment after his death.

sen.j: 不思議なことに、保典が戦死したという知らせを聞いた時、静子は何故か勝典が戦死した時のようには泣き崩れず、落ち着いた様子で戦死の事実を受け入れたという。
sen.e: Curiously, it is said that when Shizuko heard Yasusuke's death in the battle, she did not break down crying as she did when Katsusuke died in the battle and accepted his death with a sedate manner.
Curiously, it is said that when Shizuko heard Yasusuke's death in the battle, she did not break down crying as she did when Katsusuke died in the battle and accepted his death with a sedate manner.
Curiously, it is said that when Shizuko heard Yasusuke's death in the battle, she did not break down crying as she did when Katsusuke died in the battle and accepted his death with a sedate manner.

sen.j: 一説には保典が戦死する事を予め予知していたのではないかとも言われる。
sen.e: Some people say that she foresaw Yasusuke's death in the battle.
Some people say that she foresaw Yasusuke's death in the battle.
Some people say that she foresaw Yasusuke's death in the battle.

sen.j: 全ての子供を先に亡くし、そのショックから生きた感じを見受けられないような外見になっていたといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that she did not look like a living person because of the shock that she lost all children before her death.
It is said that she did not look like a living person because of the shock that she lost all children before her death.
It is said that she did not look like a living person because of the shock that she lost all children before her death.

sen.j: 晩年は盆栽などをわずかな楽しみとしたといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that she had a little pleasure such as bonsai (a dwarf miniature potted tree) in her later years.
It is said that she had a little pleasure such as bonsai (a dwarf miniature potted tree) in her later years.
It is said that she had a little pleasure such as bonsai (a dwarf miniature potted tree) in her later years.

sen.j: 明治45年7月、明治天皇が糖尿病により逝去。
sen.e: On July 1912, the Emperor Meiji died of diabetes mellitus.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On July 1912, Emperor Meiji died of diabetes mellitus.
On July 1912, Emperor Meiji died of diabetes mellitus.

sen.j: その後の大正元年9月13日、明治天皇を追って希典と共に乃木邸（現在の東京・港区 (東京都)赤坂 (東京都港区)にある乃木神社）にて胸を突き殉死。
sen.e: After that, on September 13, 1912, she committed martyrdom for the Emperor Meiji by stabbing in the chest with Maresuke at his residence (the present Nogi-jinja Shrine at Akasaka, Minato Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, on September 13, 1912, she committed martyrdom for Emperor Meiji by stabbing herself in the chest with Maresuke at his residence (the present Nogi-jinja Shrine at Akasaka, Minato Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).
sen.cmt: theを削除しました。Herselfを追加しました。
sen.e: After that, on September 13, 1912, she committed martyrdom for Emperor Meiji by stabbing herself in the chest with Maresuke at his residence (the present Nogi-jinja Shrine at Akasaka, Minato Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).

sen.j: 享年54。
sen.e: Her age at death was 54.
Her age at death was 54.
Her age at death was 54.

sen.j: 湯地定之・湯地貞子夫妻の末っ子として誕まれたこともあってか、両親・兄姉らに蝶よ花よと大切に育てられた。
sen.e: Partly because she was born as the youngest child between Sadayuki YUCHI and Sadako YUCHI, she was nursed by her parents, brothers and sisters.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Partly because she was born as the youngest child between Sadayuki YUCHI and Sadako YUCHI, she was nursed by her parents, brothers and sisters.
Partly because she was born as the youngest child between Sadayuki YUCHI and Sadako YUCHI, she was nursed by her parents, brothers and sisters.

sen.j: この為、性格は内向的で、体もさほど丈夫ではなかった。
sen.e: Therefore, she was introversive and was not blessed with good health.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, she was introversive and was not blessed with good health.
Therefore, she was introversive and was not blessed with good health.

sen.j: 当時はまだ写真撮影が高価な時代であったため、若いころの写真が残っていない。
sen.e: Since photography was still expensive in those days, her photo in her young age does not remain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since photography was still expensive in those days, her photo in her young age does not remain.

sen.j: 本人であると確認できる写真は晩年のころのものしか無い。
sen.e: The photograph which can be confirmed to be hers is only the one taken in her later years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The photograph which can be confirmed to be hers is only the one taken in her later years.
The photograph which can be confirmed to be hers is only the one taken in her later years.

sen.j: が、若い頃は顔立ちの美しい女性だったと言われる。
sen.e: However, it is said that she was beautiful when she was young.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it is said that she was beautiful when she was young.

sen.j: 出でましてかへります日のなしときく けふの御幸に逢ふぞかなしき
sen.e: It is a pity to see today's gyoko (royal visit) with hearing that the Emperor goes out but does not return.
It is a pity to see today's gyoko (royal visit) with hearing that the Emperor goes out but does not return.

sen.j: - 湯地定之：鹿児島藩侍医。
sen.e: Sadayuki YUCHI, a doctor of the Kagoshima domain.

sen.j: - 湯地貞子：武士である池田家の娘で、結婚前の幼名は天伊（テイ）。
sen.e: Sadako YUCHI: a daughter of the Ikeda family who was samurai, and her childhood name was Tei.
Sadako YUCHI: a daughter of the Ikeda family who was samurai, and her childhood name was Tei.

sen.j: 結婚後の名前の読みはサダコである。
sen.e: Her name after marriage was pronounced as Sadako.
Her name after marriage was pronounced Sadako.

sen.j: 次女・三女の結婚後の名前にていの読みがあるのは実母の幼名から採られている。
sen.e: Her second and third daughters were named after their mother's childhood name after their marriages.

sen.j: - 湯地定基：貴族院議員、根室県県令（1843-1928）。
sen.e: Sadamoto YUCHI: a member of the House of Peers, a prefectural governor (1843-1928)
Sadamoto YUCHI: a member of the House of Peers, a prefectural governor (1843-1928)

sen.j: 名前の読みはサダモト。
sen.e: His name was pronounced as Sadamoto.
His name was pronounced as Sadamoto.
His name was pronounced as Sadamoto.

sen.j: - 湯地定康：大尉。
sen.e: Sadayasu YUCHI: Taijo (Captain)
Sadayasu YUCHI: Taijo (Captain)
Sadayasu YUCHI: Taijo (Captain)

sen.j: 名前の読みはサダヤス。
sen.e: His name was pronounced as Sadayuki.
His name was pronounced as Sadayuki.
His name was pronounced as Sadayuki.

sen.j: - 湯地定監：中将、貴族院議員。
sen.e: Sadanori YUCHI: Chujo (Middle Captain), a member of the House of Peers
Sadanori YUCHI: Chujo (Middle Captain), a member of the House of Peers
Sadanori YUCHI: Chujo (Middle Captain), a member of the House of Peers

sen.j: 名前の読みはサダノリ。
sen.e: His name was pronounced as Sadanori.
His name was pronounced Sadanori.
sen.cmt: asはいらないと思います。
sen.e: His name was pronounced Sadanori.

sen.j: テイカンと読まれることが圧倒的に多いが、これは誤読である。
sen.e: His name is read as Teikan more often, but this is wrong.
His name is read as Teikan more often, but this is wrong.
His name is read as Teikan more often, but this is wrong.

sen.j: 通称もしくは渾名がそのまま名前の読みとして誤って後世に伝わったと考えられる。
sen.e: It can be thought that his common name or nickname was transmitted as a true name after ages.
It can be thought that his common name or nickname was transmitted as a true name after ages.
It can be thought that his common name or nickname was transmitted as a true name after ages.

sen.j: - 名前不明：夭折したため、名前は不明。
sen.e: Her name is unknown because she died young.
Her name is unknown because she died young.
Her name is unknown because she died young.

sen.j: 永らくの間は長妹が当人（本来の長女）だとされていたため、名前も馬場貞子と思われていた。
sen.e: Since her next sister was considered to be the real eldest daughter for a long time, her name was also thought to be Teiko BABA.
Since her next sister was considered to be the real eldest daughter for a long time, her name was also thought to be Teiko BABA.
Since her next sister was considered to be the real eldest daughter for a long time, her name was also thought to be Teiko BABA.

sen.j: - 幼名不明：結婚後に馬場貞子となる。
sen.e: Her childhood name is unknown and she became Teiko BABA after marriage.
Her childhood name is unknown and she became Teiko BABA after marriage.
Her childhood name is unknown and she became Teiko BABA after marriage.

sen.j: 結婚後の名前の読みはテイコである。
sen.e: Her name after marriage was pronounced as Teiko.
Her name after marriage was pronounced as Teiko.
Her name after marriage was pronounced as Teiko.

sen.j: （母親の名前と同じ字画なので区別するためと想われる。)
sen.e: (It can be guessed that she was named Teiko in order to distinguish from her mother's name Sadako because they were written in the same Chinese characters.)
(It can be guessed that she was named Teiko in order to distinguish from her mother's name Sadako because they were written in the same Chinese characters.)
(It can be guessed that she was named Teiko in order to distinguish from her mother's name Sadako because they were written in the same Chinese characters.)

sen.j: 長姉の夭折により実質的な長女として育てられたため、永らくの間は本来の長女の名前が馬場貞子であるとされ、次女である当人が夭折したとされていた。
sen.e: Since she was fostered as an actual eldest daughter because of her elder sister's early death, it had been thought that the real eldest daughter was Teiko BABA and that she, who was actually the second eldest sister, died young for a long time.

Since she was fostered as an actual eldest daughter because of her elder sister's early death, it had been thought that the real eldest daughter was Teiko BABA and that she, who was actually the second eldest sister, died young for a long time.

Since she was fostered as an actual eldest daughter because of her elder sister's early death, it had been thought that the real eldest daughter was Teiko BABA and that she, who was actually the second eldest sister, died young for a long time.

sen.j: 希典・静子夫妻の遺体を発見したのは彼女である。
sen.e: It was she who discovered the bodies of Maresuke and Shizuko.
It was she who discovered the bodies of Maresuke and Shizuko.
It was she who discovered the bodies of Maresuke and Shizuko.

sen.j: - 湯地お六：結婚後に柴テイとなる（てい・てい子・テイ子などと表記する文献もある）。
sen.e: Oroku (お六) YUCHI: she became Tei SHIBA (柴テイ) after marriage (Tei or Teiko [てい子 or テイ子] in some documents).
sen.cmt: お六、柴テイの読み方不明です。
sen.e: Oroku (お六) YUCHI: she became Tei SHIBA (柴テイ) after marriage (Tei or Teiko [てい子 or テイ子] in some documents).
Oroku (お六) YUCHI: she became Tei SHIBA (柴テイ) after marriage (Tei or Teiko [てい子 or テイ子] in some documents).

sen.j: 静子と最も歳が近いため、特に仲が良かったといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that she was especially close to Shizuko because of the nearest age.
It is said that she was especially close to Shizuko because of the nearest age.
It is said that she was especially close to Shizuko because of the nearest age.
